column1: Croup is due to swelling around the vocal cords.
More severe cases of croup may be caused by bacteria.
The main symptom of croup is a cough that sounds like a seal barking.
Most children will have mild cold symptoms for several days before the barking cough becomes evident.
As the cough gets more frequent, the child may have trouble breathing or stridor (a harsh, crowing noise made when breathing in).
Sometimes a doctor will listen to a child cough over the phone to identify croup.

Your health care provider may prescribe medicines, such as: - Steroid medicines taken by mouth or through an inhaler - Antibiotic medicine (for some, but not most cases) Your child may need to be treated in the emergency room or to stay in the hospital if he or she: - Has breathing problems that do not go away or get worse - Becomes too tired because of problems breathing - Has bluish skin color - Is not drinking enough fluids Medicines and treatments used at the hospital may include: - Breathing medicines given with a nebulizer machine - Steroid medicines given through a vein (IV) - An oxygen tent placed over a crib - Fluids given through a vein for dehydration - Antibiotics given through a vein Rarely, a breathing tube through the nose or mouth will be needed to help your child breathe.
If the epiglottis becomes infected, the entire windpipe can swell shut.
If an airway blockage is not treated promptly, the child can have severe trouble breathing or breathing may stop completely.

Call 911 if: - Croup symptoms may have been caused by an insect sting or inhaled object - Your child has bluish lips or skin color - Your child is drooling - Your child is having trouble swallowing - There is stridor (a noise when breathing in) - There is a tugging-in of the muscles between the ribs when breathing in - Your child is struggling to breathe
Wash your hands frequently and avoid close contact with people who have a respiratory infection.
Many cases of croup can be prevented with immunizations.
